modules.description: This module implements an abstract timeline for imperative state management, providing `save` to capture the current state in constant time and `restore` to revert to a saved state. It works with an abstract type `t` representing points in time, internally tracking changes to timed references. Use cases include implementing undo/redo functionality in interactive applications or rolling back state changes during debugging and testing.

This module implements timed references with support for undo/redo operations through an abstract timeline. It provides reference operations such as `ref`, `!`, `:=`, `incr`, and `decr`, which behave like standard references but track changes over time. The `Time` submodule allows saving and restoring the state of references, enabling features like transactional updates, interactive undo/redo in editors, or speculative execution in debuggers. Additional functions like `pure_apply` and `pure_test` allow controlled execution of functions with automatic state rollback based on the result.

This module provides time points for versioning reference updates, enabling save and restore operations to track and revert changes. It works with an abstract time type `t` and monitored references. Use cases include implementing undo/redo functionality for reference modifications and checkpointing program states efficiently.

This module provides timed reference operations with state restoration capabilities, redefining standard reference updates to support time-point tracking and efficient checkpointing. It works with `Stdlib.ref` types and an abstract `Time.t` type to manage versioned reference states. Concrete use cases include implementing undo/redo functionality for reference modifications and safely testing state changes with conditional reversion.
